Award.AwardTitle: Louisiana State University VIGRE Proposal EMSW21-VIGRE
Award.AbstractNarration:
The VIGRE Project in the Department of Mathematics at Louisiana State University (LSU) will recruit and train mathematical scientists from the US to meet the demands of the scientific workplace in the twenty-first century. The program will focus on the integration of research and education at all levels: undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral. VIGRE ?research crews? (RCs), vertically integrated research groups, will provide dynamic research environments in which faculty, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates work together to make discoveries and produce publishable results. In conjunction with LSU?s core mathematics curriculum and the RCs, the department will provide additional professional development opportunities for students and postdocs through a summer VIGRE program, through the Research Connections Program (internships in other departments on campus, in industry, or in national labs), and through various professional development workshops. The summer VIGRE program will involve participation from a consortium of regional colleges and universities. Students will participate in an REU and interact in education and outreach programs.

With solid training and mentorship, the department will produce high quality graduates and postdocs for the mathematical science and teaching workforce. It will develop the RC model as a means of transforming graduate mathematics education at LSU and as a portable mechanism for doing the same in other mathematics programs around the country. LSU graduates, with their collaborative VIGRE experience, will be able to transfer this knowledge and expertise in their various professional career paths. The VIGRE summer program and VIGRE-related outreach activities will engage Louisiana K-12 teachers and thereby have a positive impact on education throughout the state. Finally, the Research Connections Program will foster interdisciplinary research at all levels by building contacts between the department and academic, industrial, and governmental agencies

POR.DRECONTENT:
VIGRE@LSU started June 1, 2008, and was supported by a $3,741,926 NSF grant. The initial PIs were Tara E. Brendle, Gestur Olafsson (PI), and Lawrence Smolinsky. Mark Davidson was later added as CoPI after T. Brendle left LSU. The main parts of the program were:

a)     The postdoctoral program;

b)     The Traineeship program;

c)     Travel support for students;

d)     The Vertically Integrated Research, or VIR, courses;

e)     The Research connection program;

f)      Undergraduate student and the summer SMILE program;

g)     The student colloquium series; 

The grant provided support for undergraduate students, graduate students and, during the first five years of the program, postdoctoral associates. The single most important part of the undergraduate support is the SMILE summer program and the related consortium in nearby states. It provides support for 30 undergraduate students, 15 from Baton Rouge and 15 from the colleges involved in the consortium. The students participate in lectures and work on a research projects, learning LaTeX, workshops on how to apply for graduate schools, and more. At the end of the period each of the groups gives a presentation. For more information see 

https://www.math.lsu.edu/vigre/SMILE_LSU.

On the graduate student level the program supports 8--9 graduate student trainees during the academic year as well as summer support for several students.  Some of those act as mentors in the SMILE program.  Other students can participate in the Research Connection program, where they learn to deal with ``real world'' problems at research centers and labs outside of mathematics. The successful student-run Student Colloquium and our travel program were great tools to enhance our students' general knowledge of current research in different fields of mathematics and applications and to give them opportunities to interact with outside researchers.

One of the goals of the program was to transform the culture of our graduate students toward research and enhance the placement of our graduate students. This part has been quite successful. Out of 8 graduates in 2008, two got postdoctoral positions and four went on to assistant professor positions. None went to a highly ranked university. In the year 2014, we had sixteen students graduating. Six got postdoctoral positions at a research university or research center including Georgia Tech., Indiana University, and Purdue University--North Central. Seven went on to become assistant professors. In 2013 Laura Rider, a former student of P. Achar, was awarded an NSF postdoctoral support at MIT and is now a assistant professor at the University of Georgia.

Another goal was to establish a permanent postdoctoral program at LSU. Before VIGRE the department had no postdoctoral positions. As a consequence of the grant the administration established four new postdoctoral positions in the department. Before that, but during the VIGRE period, a few older lines were used for postdoctoral positions. At the moment the department has eight postdocs and research associates and four visitors.
